thread.title: The Value of Vitamin D for Athletes
thread.title_full: The Value of Vitamin D for Athletes

author: Travis Hansen
title: The Value of Vitamin D for Athletes
text:
The Value of Vitamin D for Athletes
Vitamin D undoubtedly still remains one of the most hyped and popular sports supplements on the market today. Here is a quick primer that I contributed to over at T-Nation.com that depicts how the Vitamin D pathway works in the body, along with some more evidence for athletes who may be lacking in the vitamin if you are interested:
[https://www.t-nation.com/diet-fat-loss/12-overlooked-foods-you-should-be-eating](https://www.t-nation.com/diet-fat-loss/12-overlooked-foods-you-should-be-eating%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20Research%20Please...%20%20%20There%20is%20a%20very%20interesting%20study%20that%20showed%20subjects%20who%20supplemented%20vitamin%20D%20displayed%20quicker%20muscle%20recuperation%20and%20torque%20generation%20following%20intense%20resistance%20training.%20%20Subjects%20exhibited%20around%2015%%20improvement%20in%20strength%20display%20at%2048%20hours%20and%20seven%20days%20post%20damage.%201%20%20RDA%20requirements%20for%20Vitamin%20D%20are%20low,%20but%20not%20optimal,%20so%20supplementing%20Vitamin%20D%20definitely%20may%20be%20in%20an%20athlete’s%20best%20interest%20since%20this%20micronutrient%20also%20requires%20higher%20intakes%20naturally.%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20Does%20it%20really%20work?%20%20%20Vitamin%20D%20is%20stored%20in%20the%20body%20and%20when%20it%20is%20needed%20it%20is%20converted%20into%20a%20bioactive%20hormone%20known%20as%201,25-dihydroxycalciferol.%20%20Negative%20things%20are%20associated%20with%20a%20state%20that%20attempts%20to%20produce%20the%20hormone%20but%20has%20insufficient%20vitamin%20D%20to%20do%20so,%20and%20supplementing%20vitamin%20%20D%20alleviates%20this%20possible%20negative.%20%20Thus,%20Vitamin%20D%20is%20critical%20for%20people%20in%20a%20deficient%20state.%20The%20combination%20of%20our%20indoor%20lives%20coupled%20with%20pollution%20means%20that%20most%20people%20outside%20of%20the%20tropics%20tend%20to%20be%20in%20a%20deficient%20state.%20%20Supplementing%20with%202000%20UI%20while%20you%20get%20your%20vitamin%20D%20levels%20tested%20is%20a%20smart%20way%20to%20go.%20%20So%20although%20the%20outcome%20is%20still%20beneficial,%20vitamin%20D%20supplementation%20is%20more%20about%20alleviating%20negatives%20rather%20than%20inducing%20positives.%202%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20DOSAGE%20GUIDELINES:%20%20%201,000-2,000IU%20taken%20daily%20with%20a%20meal%20is%20recommended%20in%20the%20more%20active%20and%20effective%20D3%20form%20(cholecalciferol).%20There%20was%20one%20report,%20however,%20that%20showed%20a%20higher%20upper%20limit%20for%20dosing%20and%20can%20be%20found%20here,%20and%20this%20has%20been%20reinforced%20by%20other%20credible%20experts%20as%20well.%20%20It%20appears%20that%20Vitamin%20D%20and%20K%20are%20the%20two%20types%20of%20vitamins%20that%20could%20potentially%20be%20beneficial%20at%20supraphysiological%20doses.%203%20%20%20%20%20SCIENTIFIC%20REFERENCES:%20%20#1-Owens,%20Daniel%20J.,%20et%20al.%20“A%20Systems-Based%20Investigation%20into%20Vitamin%20D%20and%20Skeletal%20Muscle%20Repair,%20Regeneration,%20and%20Hypertrophy.”%20American%20Journal%20of%20Physiology-Endocrinology%20and%20Metabolism,%20vol.%20309,%20no.%2012,%202015,%20doi:10.1152/ajpendo.00375.2015.%20%20#2-https://tonygentilcore.com/2013/03/supplement-review-supplements-that-suck-supplements-that-work-and-supplements-that-are-underrated-part-ii/%20%20#3-https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23083379)
Research Please…
There is a very interesting study that showed subjects who supplemented vitamin D displayed quicker muscle recuperation and torque generation following intense resistance training. Subjects exhibited around 15% improvement in strength display at 48 hours and seven days post damage. 1 RDA requirements for Vitamin D are low, but not optimal, so supplementing Vitamin D definitely may be in an athlete’s best interest since this micronutrient also requires higher intakes naturally.
Does it really work?
Vitamin D is stored in the body and when it is needed it is converted into a bioactive hormone known as 1,25-dihydroxycalciferol. Negative things are associated with a state that attempts to produce the hormone but has insufficient vitamin D to do so, and supplementing vitamin D alleviates this possible negative. Thus, Vitamin D is critical for people in a deficient state. The combination of our indoor lives coupled with pollution means that most people outside of the tropics tend to be in a deficient state. Supplementing with 2000 UI while you get your vitamin D levels tested is a smart way to go. So although the outcome is still beneficial, vitamin D supplementation is more about alleviating negatives rather than inducing positives. 2
DOSAGE GUIDELINES:
1,000-2,000IU taken daily with a meal is recommended in the more active and effective D3 form (cholecalciferol). There was one report, however, that showed a higher upper limit for dosing and can be found here, and this has been reinforced by other credible experts as well. It appears that Vitamin D and K are the two types of vitamins that could potentially be beneficial at supraphysiological doses. 3
SCIENTIFIC REFERENCES:
#1-Owens, Daniel J., et al. “A Systems-Based Investigation into Vitamin D and Skeletal Muscle Repair, Regeneration, and Hypertrophy.”
American Journal of Physiology-Endocrinology and Metabolism, vol. 309, no. 12, 2015, doi:10.1152/ajpendo.00375.2015.
#2-https://tonygentilcore.com/2013/03/supplement-review-supplements-that-suck-supplements-that-work-and-supplements-that-are-underrated-part-ii/
#3-https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23083379
RECOMMENDED FOR YOU
MOST POPULAR
